Its a minor style issue, but I always start the newline right after the '(' whenever all the function arguments don't fit on one line. I'm not sure whether whatever editor you use automatically indents python, but emacs does so using a style that seems to exactly match most upstream neutron code. If I were to edit this code in emacs, it would try to re-align subport_id directly under context. Starting the newline after the '(' causes it to align the following args to the left, indented 4 spaces to the right of the first line of the function call.

I'm not in favor of doing style changes for someone's editor preferences, but I am in favor of being consistent with upstream.  The example shown here doesn't follow this indentation style: https://docs.openstack.org/hacking/latest/user/hacking.html#calling-methods. It also references reading pep8, which has this: https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0008/#indentation. In the above case, I think it follows the latter two examples listed as good in PEP8, so I'll change this one to use that convention, but for cases where they can align with the parameter in the line above, I'll keep that indentation.

What I was suggesting is consistent with the following quote from the PEP8 document you referenced: "When using a hanging indent the following should be considered; there should be no arguments on the first line and further indentation should be used to clearly distinguish itself as a continuation line."

It does look like vertical alignment is acceptable as well, so I won't insist on any changes to this type of indentation.

I personally prefer the hanging intent style, is it provides much more usable space on the subsequent lines, so I try to use it consistently on all the code I write or edit. If all arguments fit on the line with the function name, that's what I do; otherwise I do a hanging indent and pack as many arguments as fit on each subsequent line. I do make exceptions to this for LOG statements, since the function names are short and its often helpful to grep for these. I also sometimes make exceptions to the packing when arguments fall into natural groups.

The problem is that 3.0.0 does not properly filter to determine if the python version is py2 or py3.  3.0.1 does check correctly.

So by setting this to != 3.0.0  it will automatically use 3.0.1 if in the future we change our env to py3, but will stay at 2.6.0 as long as we are using py2

Thank you Akihiro for the sdk patch. That's a definitely a useful improvement. However IIUC it's not transitively enforced here, right?

Sean: I'm still a bit confused about that behavior. If we allow later pip installs to upgrade packages compared to what we have in lower-constraints.txt then what exactly are we testing with a lower-constraints job?

I proposed a fix to openstacksdk.
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/701706/

The trick is that we don't upgrade packages.

https://opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient/src/branch/master/tox.ini#L142

The lower-constraints job tells it to install the requirements (the two -r lines) and constrain it using this lower-constraints.txt file (the -c) rather than using the published upper-constraints that jobs normally use:

https://opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient/src/branch/master/tox.ini#L19

The *should* result in only the versions defined in here being installed so that we are testing that what we say is the lowest versions that can be used actually do install and work as expected.

3.4.0 was definitely wrong and first I did not know which version to go with instead. But now I think anything above 4.0.0 is good like 4.4.1 that got installed in the gate run you linked to.

There's still a piece I don't understand though: If I put 4.0.0 here tox still installs 4.4.1...

I checked the source code of decorator. @decorator.decorate used in openstacksdk only exists since decorator 4.0.0. I am okay with patch set 10. I will propose the corresponding change to openstacksdk from now.

Could you mention why decorator in lower-constraints is updated per this discussion?

As far as a higher version being installed, in the lower-constraints job that can happen if one of the other dependencies specifies a higher minimum.

In other jobs, typically pip will install the highest version it can, limited by what is in upper-constraints (the -c in the tox.ini deps setting). So that may be what you're seeing with 4.4.1 being installed.
What is wrong if decorator 3.4.0 is used? openstacksdk lower-constraints.txt contains decorator==3.4.0. Is it a problem in OSC?

I confirmed the lower-constraints job of OSC failed with decorator 3.4.0.

decorator is installed as a dependency of openstacksdk, but surprisingly it works with openstacksdk lower-constraints job.
Anyway it looks like we need to update the lower bound of decorator in openstacksdk.

openstackclient/network/v2/router.py.message:
It's good we're adding this note, but maybe we should make it a stronger note by moving things around?

"This is deprecated in favor of 'router add/remove route' since it is prone to race conditions between concurrent clients when not used together with --no-route to overwrite the current value of 'routes'."
nit: s/routes - outside of scope of change, just noticed
This removes a single specified route only, so how about "route" instead?

The property name is routes on the API, isn't it good to have the same here? And the option can be repeated.

The devil's advocate from here: from the experience from this patch: https://review.opendev.org/650062, the cli can have other names than the API, so amotoki can be right here.

Here we document the cli parameter, not the API, so I think we need to stick with the singular form. The plural form would conflict with the cli syntactical convention of repeating the parameter for multiple values.
Yeah, --route option corresponds to a single route, so the singular form looks reasonable to me.

and just 'route' here

I think the text should be as close to consistent as possible to avoid confusion.  Perhaps:

"Add extra routes to a router"

"Router to which extra routes will be added (name or ID)."

"Add extra routes to a router. " ...

Same comment applies to remove.
Done. Used 'extra static route', because in my understanding the 'extra' means the user can only manipulate the static routes which are not implicitly managed by the attached subnets of the router.
IMHO "extra static routes" is easier to understand than "extra static entries". "entries" in a routing table works, but "extra static routes" is straight-forward.

It is due to the consistency with the existing code in OSC. See SetRouter below. I don't know the reason why 'gateway' was chosen when implemented, but at least the consistency is better. If needed, we can deprecate and replace it once. (it is out of scope of the patch.)
ok, sounds good for me. I was just curious

releasenotes/notes/router-extraroute-ato.message: Trivial nit, but I've always taken the stance that since release notes are read after a release has been done to see what is included, the text should be in past tense. So I think "Added" would be more appropriate, but that's just me, and really not that important.
I'm okay with both, just tell me which one to use.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: When does that happen?
bindep will never be able to install "right" version. Installing a extra yum repository and activating it is far outside bindep design.
I'm not sure to understand what would be the right version. If the version installed by bindep is not right, then why not removing docker from the bindep conf?

The issue here, is by default install-docker role pulls from non distro docker (upstream) and bindep has no way to by default add upstream URLs for repos. So, if both roles are used to install docker by default they conflict.

I agree removing docker from bindep.txt is likely good step, but at same token, this role should atleast idempotent if possible. Removing existing docker, to then use upstream seems like a good choice too.
This sounds like a bindep issue workaround and perhaps it would be more efficient to ensure bindep install the right version?

I encountered it on dashboard.zuul.ansible.com instance and was happening because a project had "docker" package listed in its bindep. Bindep install happens before so when install-docker runs it fails due to conflicts.

I do not see any concerns with the new feature because it only makes the role more resilient to the system state, without changing documented behaviours.

doc/source/admin/drivers/pagure.rst.message:
This paragraph says that the source whitelist is optional, but I don't see any code for that.

I'm really uncomfortable with source whitelisting.  It's not at all secure, and it's fragile.  I might be convinced that it's an okay option to have for debugging or something, but I don't think we can recommend it for production.  I'd rather we not have it at all.  Other similar systems manage to have cryptogrophic verification without this.

Ultimately what's needed is for Pagure to supply a token along with every webhook that it sets up that allows recipients of that webhook to verify the validity of supplied data.  Is there something like that?  If not, would the Pagure maintainers be open to adding it?

Thanks for the review, yes that's a mistake from a copy/paste from a previous abandoned patch.

Ok, yes, having only the whitelist system will be flawed. I will bring back the token fetching from the API and keep both solutions. If a webhook source is not part of the whitelist then zuul-web will try to fetch the webhook token and verify the signature. I'll advice in the doc that the whitelist system is only for debugging purpose and should not be used in production.

I want to keep both because today, on Pagure, to fetch the webhook token (generated randomly/by project server side), the API client needs to be a collaborator with *admin* right level to the project. @stephen, I want to reopen this discussion. I understand and don't object the intention to remove the cpu_policy and the cpu_pinning_requeseted properties from instance NUMA cell object. But for adding the 'cpu_policy' property to instance NUMA topology object, I have some different opinion.

'if instance_topology.cpu_policy in (field.CPUAllocationPolicy.DEDICATED and field.CPUAllocationPolicy.MIXED) '

or 'if instance_topology.cpu_policy in (field.CPUAllocationPolicy.SHARED and field.CPUAllocationPolicy.MIXED) '

while using 'if instance_topology.cpu_pinning_requested'
or 'if instance_topology.cpu_sharing_requested' is more concise.

The meaning of 'cpu_pinning_requested' and 'cpu_sharing_requested' is also very clear to understand.
'cpu_pinning_requested' means if the instance requested any pinning CPU. and 'cpu_pinning_requested' refers to if instance requests any sharing CPUs.

I had this disussion with sean-k-mooney Monday. If a user is using realtime, is there any reason to support three types of CPU: realtime+dedicated, non-realtime+dedicated, and non-realtime+shared? I was thinking perhaps we could say you only need to set 'cpu_realtime_mask' in that case and we'd treat it as an alias of 'pinned_cpus'. Thoughts?

> > So, for a user using realtime, here, for a mixed instance, it
 > > presents two types of CPU: realtime+dedicated+shared,
 > > realtime+shared.
 > 
 > What do you mean realtime+dedicated+shared and realtime+shared?
 > Shared/floating CPUs can't be realtime. I'm saying for mixed
 > instances without realtime, there are two types of CPU - shared and
 > dedicated - and for mixed instances with realtime there should
 > still only be two types of CPU - shared and dedicated+realtime.
 > Does that make sense?
 > 

 > realtime+shared isn't a thing. We don't allow it and I don't think
 > we want to (it doesn't make sense - how can you guarantee real-time
 > characteristics from an unpinned process?). This is forbidden for
 > 'shared' instances [1] and we should forbid it for 'shared' CPUs of
 > 'mixed' instances.
 > 

Now I understand you now. Actually we are on same page.

I'd like to let a realtime and mixed policy instance have two types CPUs, the 'shared' and the realtime(also dedicated) ones.

That could be done by what you suggested.



 > On that note, how about we use 'cpu_dedicated_mask' instead of
 > 'pinned_cpus'? Seems similar to the existing extra spec.

How about using 'dedicated_cpus' to take place 'pinned_cpus'?  The name of 'cpu_dedicated_mask' is close to 'cpu_realtime_mask', I really don't want user to think it might follow the usage of 'cpu_realtime_mask'. I hope we can specify the dedicated cpu in a way such as 'dedicatd_cpus=1,2,4-10,^4'. 'cpu_realtime_mask' only accepts a string starting with '^', such as 'cpu_realtime_cpu=^0-1'.

Another thing, if we decided to changes the name of 'pinned_cpus' to something else, should we make a commit as a update for our spec? because we said in that spec, we planned to the term 'pinned_cpus' for dedicated cpu list.

> I had this disussion with sean-k-mooney Monday. If a user is using
 > realtime, is there any reason to support three types of CPU:
 > realtime+dedicated, non-realtime+dedicated, and non-realtime+shared?

I probably not keep up with your thought well. I suppose a mixed policy instance must contain some dedicated CPU and some shared CPU, you cannot say a mixed instance has no dedicated CPU or shared CPU.
So, for a user using realtime, here, for a mixed instance, it presents two types of CPU: realtime+dedicated+shared, realtime+shared. 

 > I was thinking perhaps we could say you only need to set
 > 'cpu_realtime_mask' in that case and we'd treat it as an alias of
 > 'pinned_cpus'. Thoughts?

If we make 'pinned_cpus' as an alias of 'cpu_realtime_mask' for a mixed instance when 'cpu_realtime_mask' exists, that means we only support the 'realtime+shared' CPU type for a realtime instance use case, because all dedicated CPUs are realtime CPUs.

Actually I don't know any of the scenario which uses some realtime virtual CPUs for guaranteed latency, and some exclusively used host CPUs for, maybe, high speed, and some shared CPUs for increasing VM density. 
I do see some scenario for demanding shared CPUs and dedicated CPUs, or demanding the shared CPUs and realtime CPUs. Such as voice processing, and network package processing.

I am good to take 'pinned_cpus' as an alias of 'cpu_realtime_mask' and take value from it for realtime use case.

> > I had this disussion with sean-k-mooney Monday. If a user is
 > using
 > > realtime, is there any reason to support three types of CPU:
 > > realtime+dedicated, non-realtime+dedicated, and non-realtime+shared?
 > 
 > I probably not keep up with your thought well. I suppose a mixed
 > policy instance must contain some dedicated CPU and some shared
 > CPU, you cannot say a mixed instance has no dedicated CPU or shared
 > CPU.

Correct.

 > So, for a user using realtime, here, for a mixed instance, it
 > presents two types of CPU: realtime+dedicated+shared,
 > realtime+shared.

What do you mean realtime+dedicated+shared and realtime+shared? Shared/floating CPUs can't be realtime. I'm saying for mixed instances without realtime, there are two types of CPU - shared and dedicated - and for mixed instances with realtime there should still only be two types of CPU - shared and dedicated+realtime. Does that make sense?


 > > I was thinking perhaps we could say you only need to set
 > > 'cpu_realtime_mask' in that case and we'd treat it as an alias of
 > > 'pinned_cpus'. Thoughts?
 > 
 > If we make 'pinned_cpus' as an alias of 'cpu_realtime_mask' for a
 > mixed instance when 'cpu_realtime_mask' exists, that means we only
 > support the 'realtime+shared' CPU type for a realtime instance use
 > case, because all dedicated CPUs are realtime CPUs.

realtime+shared isn't a thing. We don't allow it and I don't think we want to (it doesn't make sense - how can you guarantee real-time characteristics from an unpinned process?). This is forbidden for 'shared' instances [1] and we should forbid it for 'shared' CPUs of 'mixed' instances.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/20.1.0/nova/virt/hardware.py#L1869-L1870

 > Actually I don't know any of the scenario which uses some realtime
 > virtual CPUs for guaranteed latency, and some exclusively used host
 > CPUs for, maybe, high speed, and some shared CPUs for increasing VM
 > density.
 > I do see some scenario for demanding shared CPUs and dedicated
 > CPUs, or demanding the shared CPUs and realtime CPUs. Such as voice
 > processing, and network package processing.
 > 
 > I am good to take 'pinned_cpus' as an alias of 'cpu_realtime_mask'
 > and take value from it for realtime use case.

Okay, so it seems we're in agreement.

On that note, how about we use 'cpu_dedicated_mask' instead of 'pinned_cpus'? Seems similar to the existing extra spec.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: I'm not sure about this. As I understand it, you're hoping to repurpose the 'InstanceNUMACell.cpu_pinning' field to both track the list of cores that should be pinned and then, later, the actual pinning information. I haven't yet seen the patch to do the former but I assume it comes later in the series and, because 'cpu_pinning' is a dict of ints, you're setting the values to e.g. '-1'. However, is there any reason to do this instead of adding a new 'pcpuset' field like we did for the (host) 'NUMACell' object? This is what I was expecting and I think it would be clearer. What do you think?

> yes, if we have separated filed, then the cpu_pinning won't be
 > mixed with many meaning. Like if the cpu_pinning is None, then it
 > is dedicated instance. If the cpu_pinning is dict, then it may be a
 > mixed instance. But in the end, we fulfill with real vcpu and pcpu
 > mapping.

Yes, good point. That adds to the confusion.

 > If we use a new pcpuset field, then we have to deal with the
 > upgrade, we need to migrate existing instance db records, to fill
 > the new field.

Not necessarily. More on this in a moment.

 > So another way is that we simplify the cpu_pinning. For mix and
 > dedicated, we always set it as dict, the key is cpu id, value is
 > -1. Then later we fill value as real pcpu id. Then we discard the
 > special value 'None'.

Okay, so at the moment we're saying we have this situation:

  shared
    cpuset = {0, 1, 2, 3}
    cpu_pinning = None

  dedicated
    cpuset = {0, 1, 2, 3}
    cpu_pinning = None

NOTE: 'cpu_pinning' would get populated after scheduling in both cases.

With this patchset we'd change that to, e.g.:

  shared
    cpuset = {0, 1, 2, 3}
    cpu_pinning = None

  mixed
    cpuset = {0, 1, 2, 3}
    cpu_pinning = {2: -1, 3: -1}

  dedicated
    cpuset = {0, 1, 2, 3}
    cpu_pinning = None

Alex is suggesting we can tweak that further to:

  shared
    cpuset = {0, 1, 2, 3}
    cpu_pinning = None

  mixed
    cpuset = {0, 1, 2, 3}
    cpu_pinning = {2: -1, 3: -1}

  dedicated
    cpuset = {0, 1, 2, 3}
    cpu_pinning = {0: -1, 1: -1, 2: -1, 3: -1}

I'm suggesting instead we tweak it to:

  shared
    cpuset = {0, 1, 2, 3}
    pcpuset = None
    cpu_pinning = None

  mixed
    cpuset = {0, 1}
    pcpuset = {2, 3}
    cpu_pinning = None

  dedicated
    cpuset = None
    pcpuset = {0, 1, 2, 3}
    cpu_pinning = None

I don't think we need DB migrations. Not yet at least. We could simply add a check like this:

  if cell.cpu_policy = DEDICATED and 'pcpuset' not in cell:
      cell.pcpuset = cell.cpuset
      cell.cpuset = None

We did something similar for the host cell here [1]. We would need a migration eventually if we wanted to remove that check, but it's only three lines so maybe it's not worth worrying about?

Thoughts? I'm not going to block on this but I do think the clear cpuset/pcpuset split would be clearer.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/20.1.0/nova/virt/hardware.py#L1113-L1114

@Alex and @Stephen, now it seems I got some sense of the concept of 'nova upgrade', and seems not too much things need to be changed for such kind of upgrade, in term of 'pcpuset' approach. 

How about I submit another subsequent 'refactor' patch based my current series, as Alex suggested,  then we make decision between 'cpu_pinning' approach and 'pcpuset' approach.

> I don't think we need DB migrations. Not yet at least. We could
 > simply add a check like this:
 > 
 > if cell.cpu_policy = DEDICATED and 'pcpuset' not in cell:
 > cell.pcpuset = cell.cpuset
 > cell.cpuset = None
 > 
 > We did something similar for the host cell here [1]. We would need
 > a migration eventually if we wanted to remove that check, but it's
 > only three lines so maybe it's not worth worrying about?
 > 

I'm thinking of few things:


First, cell.cpu_pinning is still being the mapping of vcpu and pcpu. We still need that.


Seconds, Instance numa object should be different from host numa object. When all the nodes upgrade to Train release, the host numa object's pcpuset field should be fulfilled with value. But the instance numa object is not, except we do the data migration. So I guess that three lines shouldn't just be in one place, it should be in the libvirt virt driver and in the part of generating guest numa config. So probably we add those code inside instance numa object loading method, and that do the data migration also. 


Thrid, we should tweak this API a little https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/api/openstack/compute/server_topology.py#L54, and I guess we should have somewhere similar in hardware.py which is using the "cell.vcpuset", but now it needs the "cell.vcpuset + cell.pcpuset".


 > Thoughts? I'm not going to block on this but I do think the clear
 > cpuset/pcpuset split would be clearer.


Agree with that is more clear for unload the cpu_pinning field.


So I'm thinking... Can this be done in the last patch of the series, and it is more like a refactor? 


 > 
 > [1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/20.1.0/nova/virt/hardware.py#L1113-L1114

Yes, you caught my thoughts about my using of 'InstanceNUMACell.cpu_pinning'.

I code like this and not using a 'pcpuset' field, as you proposed, is just because this is simple enough, especially there is no DB upgrade task. One confusing thing in my proposal might be I used a value '-1' for the undetermined host CPU. 

In the drafting of the spec of 'use-pcpu-and-vcpu-in-one-instance', I have had some preliminary discussion with sean-k-mooney and alex. Hope they can comment also.

yes, if we have separated filed, then the cpu_pinning won't be mixed with many meaning. Like if the cpu_pinning is None, then it is dedicated instance. If the cpu_pinning is dict, then it may be a mixed instance. But in the end, we fulfill with real vcpu and pcpu mapping.

If we use a new pcpuset field, then we have to deal with the upgrade, we need to migrate existing instance db records, to fill the new field.

So another way is that we simplify the cpu_pinning. For mix and dedicated, we always set it as dict, the key is cpu id, value is -1. Then later we fill value as real pcpu id. Then we discard the special value 'None'.

What are you trying to check here? Previously we were making sure that the 'cpu_pinning' field was populated with every core listed in 'cpuset'. That's no longer a useful check in this design so perhaps we want to just get rid of this? Or perhaps check this only if 'instance_cell.cpu_policy == dedicated' ?

If we go with the idea of adding a new 'pcpuset' field to track pinned CPUs, then we could update this to compare the size of 'pcpuset' and 'cpu_pinning' instead.

I try to catch if host CPUs are allocated for vCPUs, and fill them in the 'cpu_pining' value field. If host CPUs are not determined for vCPUs, then the value of 'cpu_pinning' is -1. After a set() operation, len(set(cpu_pinning.values)) will always be 1. 

For example, if instance cell with 4 vCPUs is not  pinned, then len(set(cpu_pinning.keys))=4,
and len(set(cpu_pinning.values)) = len(set([-1,-1,-1,-1])) = 1. Which should report the issue for un-pinning.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
These "shortnames" with a dot are'nt really valid. It's like we have a topdomain ctlplane. external. intarnalapi. etc in DNS. Are they ever used internally somehow?

Do we want the "not good" entry below only?

'standalone.ctlplane' is a FQDN, not a shortname. I.e it's
hostname: standalone
domain: ctlplane.

But ok, we always did this and it's outside the scope of this change. I will remove my -1.

maybe. Note that the logic behind, as I see it, is that stripping CloudDomain results in the shortname. Or a subdomain, if you wish. If we change that to real shortnames... well maybe that wouldn't break anything :)

I'm not sure I can get your question.
This patch only changes the "not good" 3rd line, while the lines 1-2 in this example are generated via different facilities and out of scope of this deduplication change...

I think [1] is where we are doing something strange. joining with '.' for the short. I wonder what would break if we remove everything that join using '.' to create a short. I think this change would not be required, as deduplication would happen with the "192.168.24.1  standalone.ctlplane.localdomain" type entries?


[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/src/branch/master/puppet/role.role.j2.yaml#L520-L524

magnum/api/attr_validator.py.message: Why not do it like validate_image()?
The original behaviour of validate_external_network did not return anything so I wanted to maintain that, the behaviour of the function would have to be changed if I adopted that model.  Thoughts?

magnum/drivers/heat/k8s_template_def.py.message:
Why you move these validate codes into conductor service, not apiserver?
We should output error early if user's arg is wrong.

It is possible that the network was deleted by the time we make a request to create the cluster, that is why the check is here.  It's also here in order to convert the external_network which could be a name to an ID.  It is possible that the existing value in database is an ID.
Don't need this here as already being handled here: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/489676/6/magnum/common/clients.py@82 Are you trying to cover something else?

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Title wraps at 50 chars, the rest of the commit message at 72.

magnum/drivers/common/templates/kubernet.message: Have you tested it in your local registry?

magnum/api/controllers/v1/cluster_templa.message: At best this should be a configurable setting? I feel like just setting a default flavor that probably is very specific to your platform will just add more confusion than it does good?

Yes, you are right. In fact, if you create template without specify the flavor in the current community, the default value m1.small will be set in the kubecluter.yaml file. The final result is to create the cluster host with the default m1.small but doesn't show it in the detail info. The default values set here are the same as in the template, and the default value will be ignored if a flavor is specified.
example:
magnum\drivers\k8s_fedora_atomic_v1\templates\kubecluster.yaml
  master_flavor:
      default: m1.small
magnum\drivers\k8s_fedora_ironic_v1\templates\kubecluster.yaml
  master_flavor:
    default: m1.small
magnum\drivers\k8s_coreos_v1\templates\kubecluster.yaml
  master_flavor:
    default: m1.small
Note: This is just a user experience issue. If everyone feel that it is not necessary, I can turn it off^_^

doc/source/user/kubernetes-load-balancer.message: This is incorrect, as this command does not translate to LBaaS v1. In fact it would translate to the Octavia API, which is different from LBaaS v1.

Right, LBaaSv1 has long been end-of-life and is no longer supported.  The only way to use it is to use an old version of the deprecated neutron tool.
There will be no support for LBaaSv1 in OpenStack client as it went end-of-life prior to the OpenStack client project starting.
I would recommend removing any mention of LBaaSV1 from this document.
